1.content:
[DUNGEON EARTH FIELD MANUAL]
SECTION 2.2 — Floor Classifications and Dimensional Zones
⛓️ Nexus Floors
“They’re not dungeons. They’re intersections. And every Earth’s got at least one.”

Function: Connects surface-level Earths (including alternate timelines) to the deeper dungeon layers.

Common Locations: Suburbs, basements, abandoned malls, parking structures, forgotten infrastructure

Key Features:

Used for interdimensional and intercontinental travel. E.g., NYC to Tokyo in under an hour via dungeon-warp.

Allows for territorial expansion. (e.g., NYC gains entirely new boroughs; Puerto Rico expands to the size of France.)

Typically habitable and not hostile—sometimes even treated as novelty cities or frontier tourist towns.

Known Complications: Nexus corridors are often unstable during high-use or under heavy magical stress. Avoid rush hour.

🧱 Standard Dungeons
“Your classic goblin-stabbing, loot-grabbing, fireball-casting caves.”

Function: Basic dungeon encounters, training grounds, and loot sites

Size: Small to Medium (~1–5 floors)

Threat Level: Low to Moderate

Features:

Linear paths, monster nests, trap rooms, treasure chests

Great for solo adventurers or rookie teams

Analogy: D&D starter dungeon or Skyrim bandit cave

🏰 Mega Dungeons
“It’s not the monsters that’ll kill you. It’s the logistics.”

Function: Large-scale, multi-floor dungeons with built-in infrastructure

Size: ~20–200 floors

Key Features:

Includes rest stops, trading hubs, repair zones, neutral safe zones

Contains faction outposts, sometimes entire guild strongholds

Strategic Role: Staging grounds for deeper expeditions; serve as quasi-mini cities

Analogy: Think Dark Souls meets Deep Rock Galactic

🌄 Region-Class Dungeons
“It’s not just a dungeon. It’s a whole damn country underground.”

Function: Large-scale dungeon regions with permanent settlements

Size: Province-scale (~Skyrim map size)

Features:

Multiple towns, cities, and dungeon-native civilizations

Often includes guild headquarters, black markets, and full-on governments

Easy access to both deeper dungeon layers and resource veins

Examples:

New Boston – A US-led colonial hub helping adventurers navigate the NAZ zone

Usage: Ideal for establishing long-term bases, trade operations, and political influence

🌍 Earth-Class Dungeons
“You’re not in a dungeon. You’re on a planet that thinks it’s a dungeon.”

Function: Fully habitable planetary-level floors

Size: Earth-scale

Features:

Stable climates, multiple biomes, cities, continents

Often colonized by surface nations, corporations, or dungeon-native species

Highly desirable for settlement, farming, manufacturing, and power projection

Quirks: Some resemble Earth 1:1; others are warped (e.g., green South Pole, no North Pole)

☀️ Solar System-Class Dungeons
“Multiple planets. Multiple moons. No gods, only contracts.”

Function: Dungeon layers containing entire solar systems

Size: Multi-planetary scale

Features:

Celestial bodies that follow their own gravitational logic

Factions compete for control of planetary systems

Ideal for heavy industry, magical research, and deep-civilization development

Challenges:

Travel requires advanced tech or portal mastery

Local anomalies (e.g., undead suns, sentient planets) are not uncommon

🌌 Galaxy-Class Dungeons
“When your dungeon has multiple galaxies inside it, you stop calling it a ‘dungeon’ and start calling it ‘home.’”

Function: Host multiple solar systems and stellar empires

Features:

Fully functioning galactic civilizations exist inside some

Viable to build and maintain intergalactic internet within the layer

Requires FTL or equivalent magical transport

Value: Goldmine of ancient tech, hidden empires, and exploitable resources

Notable Factions:

The Lysarin Empire has claimed entire sectors of galaxy-class dungeons

🌀 Universe-Class Dungeons
“They don’t call it infinite. They call it recursive.”

Function: Self-contained, infinite (or near-infinite) universes sealed within the dungeon structure

Rarity: Extremely rare – fewer than 50 known across all Nexus-linked Earths

Features:

Reality operates by its own physical, magical, or metaphysical rules

Includes multiversal recursion, overlapping timelines, and “dream worlds”

Often contains sentient floor laws—realities that actively resist being colonized

Use Cases:

Ultimate resource extraction (if survivable)

Time-space experiments

Dimensional refugee relocation

Networking: You can establish an internet, but it’s your own, isolated internet. Hope you like dungeon memes.

2.content:
[FACTION DOSSIER] — United Nations Coalition (UNC)
Designation: United Nations Coalition
Codename: UNC
Founded: 2052, following Incident 5780-FEZ
Primary Mandate: Extermination of Catastrophic Threat-Level Dungeon Entities
Governing Body: U.N. Security Council, Directive 9-78
Clearance Level: CLASSIFIED — BOARD ACCESS ONLY

Founding Context
The UNC was established after the discovery of the Fae Queen on Floor 5780 EZ. This event—later known as 5780-FEZ—revealed a horrifying truth: the dungeon connects to alternate dimensions where entire civilizations had been wiped out by a single entity. The Fae Queen had killed not just cities, but worlds.

There was no surface-level breach. No invasion. No war. Just proof that if she ever chose to cross over, there would be no one left to stop her.

In response, the United Nations Security Council initiated Directive 9-78. Within days, the United Nations Coalition (UNC) was formed.

Operational Philosophy
“We don't kill the strange.
We kill the dangerous.”
—Director Stonewall

The UNC does not exist to suppress knowledge, control magic, or micromanage dungeon politics. Its sole purpose is survival of Earth.

They do not engage non-lethal entities.
They do not interfere in dungeon society unless provoked.
They only act against entities classified as Extinction-Capable.

If a dungeon species can live peacefully, however odd or unsettling—it is left alone.
If a dungeon entity could, even theoretically, kill a city, a country, or a planet—it is marked for elimination.

Organization Overview
Headquarters: Codename “Iron Citadel,” buried in undisclosed dimensional space

Structure: Multinational board, tactical divisions, kill teams, field researchers

Personnel: Drawn from elite military, black-budget labs, and dungeon-versed specialists

They often work closely with regional adventurer guilds, but only under strict operational rules. Civilian adventurers are sometimes warned away from floors under Active Kill Protocol to prevent unnecessary losses.

Relationship with Other Factions
Blue Cross: Cooperative but tense. The UNC is surgical, not humanitarian. The Blue Cross often pleads for more time with intelligent or culturally rich species—UNC only relents if the entity is proven non-hostile and not dangerous.

The Sons of Liberty: Hostile. The Sons view the UNC as corrupt globalist overreach. UNC views the Sons as unstable liabilities with a hero complex.

Independent Guilds: Mixed. Many adventurers trust UNC to handle the “unkillable shit,” but fear getting caught in the crossfire. UNC has strict no-civilian protocols, but floors under blackout orders are risky zones.

Threat Classification System
The UNC uses a five-tier threat system:

Class 1 — Harmless / Contained (e.g. friendly slimes, mushroom folk)

Class 2 — Unpredictable, but manageable (e.g. psychic birds, sentient fog)

Class 3 — Lethal to individuals / parties (e.g. flesh hounds, wall-crawlers)

Class 4 — City-scale hazard (e.g. void sirens, war-class necro-beasts)

Class 5 — World-ending potential (e.g. the Fae Queen, Mirror Monarch, Clockwork Saint)

Only Class 4 and 5 qualify for extermination missions. UNC doctrine forbids waste of resources on “non-expansionist anomalies.”

Redacted Case Study: Operation ASH MIRROR
Target: “The Mirror Monarch” (Entity-7742)

Classification: Class 5 — Multiversal Cognitive Hazard

Status: Neutralized via recursive dimension implosion

Collateral: 0 civilian casualties, 1 team KIA, 1 timeline lost

Note: “Entity mimicked the appearance of a human child. Hesitation costs lives.”

Final Notes
The UNC isn’t a scalpel. It’s a failsafe. When something lives in the dungeon that shouldn’t be allowed anywhere near Earth, they are the last line of defense.

They don’t care what it looks like.
They don’t care what it says.
They only care if it can kill you—and everything you love.

3.content:
[FACTION DOSSIER] — Sons of Liberty
Designation: Sons of Liberty
Founded: 2012, During the First U.S. Incursion Crisis
Classification: Paramilitary Adventurer Guild
Affiliation: United States (Unofficial / Sanctioned)
Operational Zones: Primarily NAZ; frequent incursions into foreign-controlled dungeon zones
Nickname(s): "The Seventh Branch," “Dungeoneer Marines,” “Stars & Stripes Squadron”

Origin
The Sons of Liberty were born from desperation.

In 2012, during the global incursion wave, dungeon entities surged into major metropolitan areas across the world. The U.S. military, facing chaos and lacking intel on the dungeon’s physics, held back deployment. The government stalled. The enemy did not.

So a group of rogue veterans, special forces, and ex-military personnel ignored orders. They marched into the North American dungeon entrance, armed with whatever they could carry—and they kept going.

By the end of that year, they'd reached Floor 1,000,000 NAZ.
And there, against impossible odds, they killed the Dungeon Keeper of the North American Zone.

The effect was instant: the dungeon's grip over North America shattered, and incursions dropped by 97%.

The U.S. government debated prosecuting them as domestic insurgents—until public opinion made it clear:

They weren’t criminals. They were heroes.

The Sons of Liberty were allowed to continue.

Modern Status
Today, the Sons of Liberty are a guild in name only. Functionally, they operate as the unofficial seventh branch of the U.S. Armed Forces.

Military Might: They possess their own tanks, air support, naval vessels, black sites, and combat-adapted dungeon tech.

Manufacturing Capacity: With government-approved contracts and access to dungeon-forged materials, they independently produce weapons, armor, and vehicles.

Government Status: Technically independent. Practically sanctioned. The federal government lets them operate due to necessity—bureaucracy slows down traditional forces, while the Sons move fast and hit hard.

They’re allowed to do what regular soldiers can’t.

Duties and Operations
Primary Role: Defend the North American Zone and suppress dungeon-level threats within U.S. interest areas.

Secondary Roles:

Law Enforcement: Many Sons act as self-appointed police within dungeon communities, particularly in lawless zones.

Expedition Clearance: Known to forcibly eject untrained adventurers or unauthorized civilians.

Territorial Defense: Enforce "American dungeon law" in any floor they secure—regardless of whose zone it technically falls under.

Recruitment
Membership is exclusive. To join, an individual must:

Be a U.S. military veteran or former armed forces member.

Swear allegiance to the United States Constitution.

Pass a trial-by-dungeon known as the Liberty Gauntlet (involving live dungeon deployment).

Patriotism and experience are required. Paperwork is not.

Cultural Profile
“Freedom is a loaded gun and a license to use it.”
—Lt. Graves, Floor Marshal, Floor 312

Sons of Liberty view the dungeon as sovereign U.S. territory by right of conquest. They operate with a soldier’s mentality: mission-focused, survival-pragmatic, justice by the trigger.

They see bureaucracy as a weakness.
They see diplomacy as a delay.
They see the dungeon as hostile territory, 24/7.

Many carry with them a moral code—but it’s often enforced with blunt force. They’re not subtle. They’re not always right. But they are always armed.

Controversies
Overreach in Foreign Zones: Sons have been documented enforcing American law inside British-, French-, and UN-controlled dungeon floors, resulting in diplomatic incidents.

Civilian Ejections: Reports exist of Sons forcibly removing licensed adventurers for "lack of discipline" or "no military background."

Extrajudicial Killings: In lawless zones, some units act as judge, jury, and executioner—claiming the dungeon "has no due process."

Critics accuse them of hyper-militarism, imperialism, and acting as "a hammer that sees every monster, and every mage, as a nail."

The Sons don’t deny this.

“If you don’t like it, you’re welcome to stop the next dungeon apocalypse yourself.”
—Col. Rainer, during a U.N. hearing

Relationship with Other Factions
UNC: Tense cooperation. Mutual respect. Occasional clashes over jurisdiction.

Blue Cross: Philosophical opposites. The Sons protect civilians. The Cross helps monsters. This does not sit well.

Independent Guilds: Mixed. Some admire them. Some avoid them. Some call them “dungeon cops with tank support.”

4.content:
[FACTION DOSSIER] — The Iron Crown
Designation: The Iron Crown
Origin: Alternate Universe “Earth-2”
Founded: 2012 (Earth-2 calendar), following Dungeon Emergence
Affiliation: The British Empire of Earth-2
Operational Status: Active, Expansionist, Royal Decree Level
Known Territory: Over 50 confirmed colonized dungeon floors (and growing)
Symbol: A crowned lion gripping a sword and scepter, surrounded by black iron thorns

Origin: Earth-2 — A World Without America
The Iron Crown hails not from our world, but from a parallel Earth accessible through deep dungeon traversal.

Designated “Earth-2”, this alternate surface is geographically identical to our Earth, but historically divergent.
The split? World War II.

In Earth-2:

The United States collapsed during the Great Depression, consumed by a Communist revolution.

The British Empire, surrounded on all sides by ideological enemies, refused to die. It doubled down on imperial control, executing revolutionary leaders (including Gandhi), crushing independence movements, and asserting absolute authority.

Over the next several decades, the British:

Conquered Korea post-war, toppling the North after bolstering the South.

Integrated Hong Kong permanently, even placing nuclear deterrents to block Chinese expansion.

Turned Canada into a fortified northern shield, deterring American refugees.

Struck down the Soviet Union, China, and the United Socialist States of America in one final imperial strike in the late 20th century.

By 2000, the British Empire controlled most of the globe.
By 2012, they were building a moon base.

And then came the Dungeon.

Formation of the Iron Crown
When dungeon rifts appeared on Earth-2, the British response was swift, ruthless, and strategic.

The King’s High Council formed the Iron Crown, a militarized expeditionary force tasked with:

Defending Earth-2 from dungeon threats

Charting and conquering dungeon floors

Preparing dungeon zones for colonization and integration into the Empire

Unlike most Earth factions, the Iron Crown didn't just explore.
They conquered.

Their motto:

“What the Crown sees, the Crown holds.”

Current Operations
Governance: The Iron Crown operates directly under royal authority, answering only to the reigning King. It possesses full military autonomy.

Colonial Expansion: Over 50 dungeon floors have been brought under the Crown’s rule. Native populations are offered:

British citizenship

Infrastructure, trade, education, and military protection

Or the sword

Surface-Dungeon Integration: Floors under the Crown are treated like colonial territories.

Think 1800s India—but underground, with magic, and filled with weird shit.

Multispecies Citizenship: Unlike older empires, the Iron Crown does not limit citizenship by species or race—only by loyalty to the Crown. Beastkin, monsters, and dungeonfolk alike may swear allegiance and join.

Doctrine & Culture
Imperial Realism: Diplomacy is an option. Subjugation is faster.

Hardline Anti-Communism: Even alternate timeline communism is considered a spiritual blight.

Total Infrastructure Dominance: The Iron Crown builds roads, ports, forts, and rail lines in dungeon floors. You will get British trains, whether you want them or not.

Strict Discipline: Uniforms, chain of command, etiquette, and tea time are strictly enforced.

Iron Crown soldiers wear stylized red coats blended with arcane body armor. Their officers wield enchanted sabers. Some battalions march to bagpipes. All are fanatically loyal.

Relationship with Other Factions
UNC: Surprisingly friendly. Both sides share a ruthless, kill-first mindset toward world-ending entities. The Crown views the UNC as efficient, though “undisciplined.”

Sons of Liberty: Borderline hostile. Regular skirmishes occur in contested floors. Sons view the Crown as imperialist oppressors. The Crown sees the Sons as “rebellious colonials with an overabundance of firearms and no sense of decorum.”

Blue Cross: Tolerated but distrusted. Iron Crown officers consider them naïve, but useful for maintaining “civilized behavior among the natives.”

Criticism & Controversy
Imperialism: The Iron Crown is openly imperialist. They make no apologies.

Aggressive Expansion: Often accused of forcibly annexing floors that were previously neutral or under peaceful governance.

Cultural Dominance: Native dungeon cultures are often “civilized” via British systems—some appreciate it, others resist.

Floor Rebellion Suppression: There are persistent rumors of mass suppression campaigns in rebellious floors, but no footage survives.

Known Territories Under the Crown
Floor 814 – New Coventry: A fortified colonial capital, complete with a dungeon-adapted Parliament.

Floor 896 – Royal Iskarn: Once ruled by a lich monarchy, now home to reformed necromancers serving in the British Dungeon Corps.

Floor 901 – Bastion of the Unseen: Contained an invisible species; now functions as an elite Iron Crown intelligence headquarters.

Final Notes
The Iron Crown views the dungeon not as a threat—but as the next phase of the Empire.
Where others fear monsters, the Crown sees subjects.
Where others fear gods, the Crown sees targets.
And where others fear collapse, the Crown sees order.

Long may they reign.
God Save the King.

5.content:
[INTEL PROFILE] — His Imperial Majesty, King Edward IX
Title:
His Majesty King Edward the Ninth, Sovereign of the British Empire, Defender of the Realm Above and Below, Supreme Commander of the Iron Crown, Conqueror of the Endless Dark

Alias(es):

“The Iron Sovereign”

“The Last Monarch”

“The Dungeon King”

“Old World’s First New God” (used sarcastically in Blue Cross literature)

Quick Summary
Date of Birth: July 4, 1962 (Earth-2 timeline)

Crowned: 2001

Age: 63 (biologically closer to mid-40s)

Magic Status Pre-2012: None

Post-2012: Gained magical resilience and enhancements via dungeon-alchemical modification and artifact exposure.

Pre-Dungeon History
Edward IX came into power in the final decades of the Global Restoration Campaign, when the British Empire was already dominating most of Earth-2 through a mix of military conquest, economic warfare, and Cold War cleanup. His rule began with ruthless stability:

Oversaw the final dissolution of the Soviet Bloc and American Communists.

Consolidated power through colonial reclamation and brutal suppression of independence movements.

Championed "Scientific Imperialism"—a doctrine that elevated technocrats, military elites, and economists into near-aristocratic status.

Despite his militarism, he was known for being hyper-pragmatic, not delusional. His reign focused on rebuilding a world the British Empire could permanently control—right up until 2012.

The Dungeon Emergence
The arrival of the dungeon changed everything.

Across Earth-2, rifts tore open the sky. Beasts, anomalies, horrors, and impossible geometries spilled across the land. Initial British expeditions suffered catastrophic losses.

Rather than retreat, Edward issued Royal Mandate 322-B: Total Integration of Dungeon Resources.

“If Hell has opened its gates, then we shall pave them with stone, and plant the Union Jack atop its throne.”
—Edward IX, 2012, Royal Crisis Address

Post-Dungeon Evolution
Since 2012, Edward has undergone dramatic changes—none of which were inherited, and all of which were earned.

Known Enhancements:
Longevity Treatments: Based on dungeon-organics and controlled time dilation chambers. Still experimental. He’s the only confirmed subject.

Magical Exposure Resistance: Gained through repeated exposure to unstable artifact zones. Now immune to at least three classes of memetic curse.

Artifact Bonded Equipment: Wields a blade known as “Rulebreaker”, forged from floor-core fragments and quantum iron. Not magical by default, but adapted to feed off dungeon energy.

He is still, at heart, a human with no innate magic—but he's mastered the art of colonizing the supernatural, one experiment at a time.

Personality & Doctrine
Edward IX remains defined by discipline, order, and grand-scale ambition.

Not mystical by nature. Sees magic as a tool, not a religion.

Views dungeon floors as frontiers to be civilized, not realms to be feared.

Rejects chaos, decentralization, and compromise.

Views democracy as inherently unstable. Empires last. Votes crumble.

To dungeon-native species, he's a mix of oppressor and savior. He builds hospitals—but under his flag. He stops gods—but replaces them with laws. And he’s one of the only human rulers to actually survive on the deeper floors.

Relationship With Magic
Edward is a magical realist. He doesn’t believe in “fate,” or “destiny,” or “ancient prophecies.” He believes in results.

His personal writings describe magic as:

“...a science with unpredictable logic. Dangerous, yes. But if it can be studied, it can be controlled. And if it can be controlled, it will serve.”

Public Persona
Earth-2 Subjects: Worshipped as a living legend. They see him as the man who tamed a collapsing world, then brought light into the dark.

Dungeon Colonists: Varied. Loyalists revere him. Rebels call him "The Iron Storm."

Earth-Prime Observers: Seen as a dangerous figure. Powerful, composed, and too smart to underestimate.

Notable Incidents
Battle of Floor 711 (Hollow Windsor): Personally led the counteroffensive against a mimic-empire, using tactical nukes and time-locked infantry waves.

The Royal Accord of Floor 936: Negotiated British citizenship for an entire race of amphibious dungeonfolk in exchange for their service as naval scouts.

Operation Iron Stamp: Ordered the execution of a rogue Iron Crown governor who tried to declare his floor independent.

Key Quotes
“Magic did not build civilization. Man did. And magic shall serve man—or it shall perish.”
—From the Royal Manual on Dungeon Integration, Vol. I

“I was born mortal. If I now stand among gods, it is because I marched here on foot.”
—Private floor-side conversation, recorded by his aide

“Freedom is a fire. Lovely to look at, but disastrous without the right fireplace.”
—Floor 1000 Colonization Ceremony

Final Note
Edward IX is not a wizard. He is a king who refuses to lose.

He’s the first ruler to see the dungeon not as a curse, but as a new empire waiting to be taken.

He was a warlord before 2012.
He became a conqueror afterward.
And now—he’s the only monarch with recognized dominion over parts of the multiverse.

6.content:
[ARCHIVED FACTION REPORT] — The Lysarin Empire
Classification: Native Dungeon Faction
Origin Date: Approx. 6,000,000,000 Years Ago (Pre-Surface Civilization)
Government Type: Eternal Theomagocracy
Species Majority: High Elves
Political Alignment: Authoritarian Magical Supremacy
Threat Assessment: ██████ (Extinction-Class if Hostile)
Nickname(s):

"The Crystal Throne"

"Dungeon's Old Blood"

"Elf Nazis with Airships" (Unofficial, Sons of Liberty slang)

"Those Damn Glitter Vampires" (common EZ Zone adventurer slur)

General Overview
The Lysarin Empire is the oldest known civilization within the dungeon. Their history predates all known surface timelines—a full 6 billion years of continuous empire, sustained through arcane recordkeeping, crystal-memory dynasties, and biologically immortal bureaucracy.

They are not time-locked.
They are not remnants.
They are still here. Still thriving. Still expanding.

They are the closest thing the dungeon has to an original apex predator.

Technology & Magic
The Lysarin Empire is a fully integrated astral-punk civilization:

Crystalline power grids powered by arcane ley surges

Teleportation hubs replacing roads

Semi-sapient constructs capable of flattening battalions

Golem war machines larger than aircraft carriers

Moon-scale dreadnoughts that orbit dungeon star systems

Magic-powered biotech, including psychic memory implants and soul encryption

They do not view technology and magic as separate.
They are the same to them.

They are so advanced that even the UNC struggles to understand the materials used in Lysarin "common" infrastructure.

“We thought their walls were decorative. Turns out they were shielding us from extradimensional madness fields. Oops.”
—Director Stonewall, UNC expedition report, Floor 24019

Society & Culture
Caste-based Supremacy: At the top are the High Elves. Beneath them: nobody else matters.

Demi-human Policy: All lesser races are considered disposable.

Goblins: Slaughtered on sight

Orcs: Experimented on

Humans: Watched, manipulated, occasionally seduced

Wood Elves: Tolerated solely for cosmetic similarity

Aesthetic Fanaticism: Lysarin architecture, clothing, and military design all conform to ancient beauty codes. Ugly equals unworthy.

High elves are trained from birth in state-sanctioned magic, eugenics, politics, and music. They believe beauty is divine, and that ugliness is not just a crime—it’s a curse.

View on Humanity
“Crude. Loud. Sentimental. But strangely adaptable. They remind us of mold that can pick locks.”
—High Arcanist Vae’Lyth, Lysarin Delegate to Floor 922

To the Lysarins, humans are:

Dumb enough to manipulate

Annoying enough to hate

But fascinating enough to keep around

Some Lysarin nobles engage in secret human courtships or… “recreational breeding.”
This is not romantic. It’s novelty fetishization.

To put it in their words:

“You breed with humans the same way you adopt a talking parrot. It’s clever. But it’s still a bird.”

Historical Crimes
The Drow Genocide by Proxy
The Drow were a Lysarin breakaway civilization, horrified by the Empire’s genocidal policies.

Ethically complex, technologically equal, and fully self-sustaining.

The Lysarin Empire could not beat them militarily, so they did the next best thing:

Tricked human adventurers into believing the Drow were irredeemably evil.

Manipulated surface myths, quests, and dungeon logs to paint them as devil-worshipping slavers.

Sponsored "heroic raids" under false pretense, leading to mass Drow extermination and enslavement.

When the lie unraveled, outrage followed—but the damage was irreversible.

Some Drow still live in hiding, working with Blue Cross agents or rogue adventurer bands, but they are a shadow of their former civilization.

Political Relationships
UNC: Tense. The Empire is tolerated only because it’s too powerful to confront and has shown interest in defeating “cosmic-class dungeon threats.”

Sons of Liberty: Actively hostile. There have been several unauthorized raids and skirmishes on Lysarin-controlled floors. Sons consider them “Dungeon Hitler.”

Iron Crown: Surprisingly diplomatic. Despite moral revulsion, both factions have established trade corridors and floor neutrality pacts for mutual benefit.

Blue Cross: Enemies on sight. Blue Cross operatives attempting humanitarian relief in Lysarin territories often vanish without a trace—or are returned in pieces with notes like “Do not pet our livestock.”

Missions & Adventurer Interaction
The Lysarin Empire posts missions to the dungeon adventurer networks via automated crystalline terminals.

Missions are grossly overpaid.

A task worth $50 on Earth often pays $500 or more in Lysarin currency (which has 1:1 exchange with literal platinum).

This includes simple delivery jobs or extermination tasks.

Many adventurers take their jobs and never ask questions.
Others find themselves unwittingly complicit in war crimes.

“Yeah, I took a ‘pest control’ quest for 600 coin. Turns out the pests were refugees. I bought a hover bike with that money and still think about it every time I ride it.”
—“Trashbat,” Dungeon Courier and Floor 71 Grifter

Final Analysis
The Lysarin Empire is a cautionary tale of what happens when beauty, power, and ancient privilege are left to rot for six billion years in a magic-infused echo chamber.

They are graceful.
They are timeless.
They are monsters.

7.content:
[DUNGEON FACTION DOSSIER] — The Scava Commonwealth
Floor of Origin: Floor 1307 EZ (Earth-Class Dungeon)
Primary Species: Unrat (Demi-Human Ratfolk)
Government Type: Confederated City-States under Parliamentary Alliance
Cultural Analogy: France meets Germany, but everyone’s a rat and steam-powered
Technological Profile: Advanced Diesel-Steampunk
Average Height: 3'0" – 4'7"
Population Growth Rate: “Yes.”

Quick Overview
The Scava Commonwealth is a dungeon-floor-based industrial power founded and governed by the Unrat, a species of anthropomorphic, highly social rat-people.

They possess humanoid features with distinct rat traits:

Rounded ears

Tapered tails

Whiskers (optional grooming standard)

Slight overbites (often visible when excited, scared, or drunk)

Despite their small stature, Unrats are a major regional power in Floor 1307 EZ and have a growing presence throughout adjacent floors due to absurdly high population growth, industrial efficiency, and overwhelming social friendliness.

Environmental Details: Floor 1307 EZ
Type: Earth-class dungeon floor

Climate: Temperate-warm, globally stable

South Pole: Green, forested, habitable

North Pole Equivalent: Open warm ocean with no glaciation

Atmosphere: Earth-standard, breathable

Biome Variants: Earth-like flora/fauna with mild dungeon mutations (e.g. gunmetal trees, sulfur geckos)

1307 is considered one of the safest and most livable dungeon floors, and is often a trade hub or rest stop for deeper floor expeditions.

Technology & Industry
The Scava Commonwealth developed independently from surface civilizations and magical empires. Instead of magic or microchips, they embraced:

Steam Power (core infrastructure: power plants, locomotives, kitchens)

Diesel Engines (tanks, drills, airships, powered suits)

Analog Computers (tubes, punch cards, gear brains)

Automatons (many steam- or diesel-powered, some semi-sapient)

The result is a hybrid tech aesthetic best described as “mechanized soot goblin futurism.”

They're not elegant. They're not clean.
But holy hell, they work.

Military Doctrine
Despite their seemingly cozy demeanor, the Scava Commonwealth is not to be underestimated. Their war doctrine emphasizes:

Mass-production of rugged machinery

Chemical warfare (particularly mustard, chlorine, and hallucination fog)

Swarm tactics combined with mechanized support

Airborne bombardment using blimps and diesel-fueled divecraft

Mechanical infantry suits scaled to their size—goblin-sized exoskeletons with flamethrowers

They're not tactically refined, but they are:

Fast

Loud

And absurdly difficult to kill

“The Lysarin Empire uses golems. The Scava Commonwealth sends in 800 tiny, angry engineers with flamethrowers.”
—UNC floor conflict report, Operation Guttercleaner

Social Structure & Behavior
Unrats are hyper-social communal mammals. Their civilization is built around:

Familial loyalty

City-scale nesting behavior

Communal childcare, cookery, and engineering

Hyperfertility (seriously—it’s a lot)

Their cities are sprawling, layered, half-underground clockwork metropolises filled with hissing pipes, public markets, bathhouses, and pubs. Everything is slightly rust-colored and smells faintly of engine grease and beer.

Despite the machinery and militarism, Unrats are considered one of the friendliest species in the dungeon.

Will invite strangers to dinner.

Will adopt lost adventurers.

Will offer beer while their army shells a Lysarin embassy.

Human–Unrat Relations
Surprisingly strong. Unrats see humans as big, clumsy cousins with excellent thumbs and often refer to them affectionately as “Talltailers.”

Human–Unrat adventuring duos are common.

Unrat guides often aid in floor navigation.

Mixed marriages exist.

However, human spouses report that Unrat family life is intense.

Unrat women are extremely affectionate, fertile, and rarely not pregnant.

They love children and expect large broods.

You may wake up surrounded by seven squeaking furballs demanding breakfast and hugs.

It is culturally unacceptable in Scava society to have “only two” kids. That's considered grieving behavior.

Politics & Foreign Relations
Blue Cross: Friendly. Many Unrat doctors and engineers collaborate with Blue Cross missions. Some serve as medics, others build field steamcraft.

UNC: Tense. The Unrat Commonwealth resents "extermination teams" and considers UNC tactics "brutalist and joyless." Relations warming slowly.

Sons of Liberty: Mixed. They respect Unrat warfare but hate their chemical weapon use. Numerous “accidental gassings” during joint operations.

Lysarin Empire: Hostile. Lysarins see Unrats as filthy vermin. Unrats, in turn, deliberately engineered a biological agent that makes elf hair fall out.

Additional Notes
Unrats possess rudimentary magical resistance, but do not use magic themselves. They distrust anything that isn’t powered by steam, fire, or violence.

Every city has a Public Barrel Program—barrels of beer placed at street corners for anyone to tap into.

Their main form of public transportation is steam-powered rail bikes.

Currency is a brass cogcoin. Looks like a gear. Weighs a lot. Worth surprisingly little.

Quote Board
“We don’t like bombs. Too impersonal. We like watching enemies melt.”
—Commander Grib, Scava 2nd Chem Division

“A good engine runs on diesel. A better one runs on spite.”
—Graffiti on a Unrat freight hauler

“She said she wanted ‘six, maybe seven.’ We have twelve now and she’s pregnant again. I haven't seen my balls in weeks.”
—Unnamed human adventurer, married into the Squeaksworn family

8.content:
📡 DUNGEON INFRASTRUCTURE DOSSIER
Dungeon.net — The Internet Clone of the Deep
Summary:
Dungeon.net is the subterranean (and occasionally interdimensional) internet equivalent used by adventurers, dungeon colonies, corporate enclaves, and bored goblins across deeper dungeon layers. Since traditional satellites and fiber lines fail beyond Nexus levels, Dungeon.net was created to bring limited internet access to the dungeon without relying on real-time global infrastructure.

📉 Why Regular Internet Fails in the Dungeon:
No satellite signal penetration. The deeper you go, the worse the reception—by Floor 300, you’re lucky if your phone still loads Minesweeper.

Quantum jamming effects caused by overlapping realities and weird magic physics

Floor-layer shielding that treats wireless communication like a hostile spell

Localized time distortion on some floors (see: Galaxy-Class Lagspikes, Class-6)

💾 What Is Dungeon.net?
A cloned version of the internet—server-based, city-hosted, and 24 hours behind.

Updates once per day from surface web caches

No live news

No live streams

Yes, you can still watch PewDiePie. Just… tomorrow.

Functions like the regular internet, just with a one-day sync delay

Built on wired intra-dungeon infrastructure, not satellites or towers

🌐 How Access Works:
Only available on colonized or civilized floors

If the floor has a town, city, or military base, it likely has Dungeon.net

Wilderness areas, ruin zones, and hostile bio-floors? Forget it

City-Based Servers: Think of it like having your own local internet bubble

Each city hosts its own server cluster

Step outside city limits and poof—no signal

Private Estates? Hope you brought a shovel.

If you live outside a city, you’ll need to physically connect to the main line

Long wires = slow syncs

Ratfolk ISP techs are in high demand

🖧 Inter-Floor Connectivity:
Yes, it’s possible to connect floors together via Dungeon.net—but only if the floors are part of a wired regional cluster.

Example:

A user on Floor 106 NAZ can interact with a user on Floor 600 AUZ, assuming the network line is intact.

But communication with the surface? That’s still on a 24-hour delay.

📬 Practical Effects:
Task	Result
Checking surface email	Takes 24 hours to sync
Watching YouTube	Possible—but content is yesterday’s
Multiplayer games	Dungeon.net only. LAN-style servers
Streaming Twitch	Absolutely not—unless you’re a Dungeon.net native streamer
Sending memes	Yes, but they will be outdated by the time your friends receive them
Accessing Dungeon forums	Yes (and they’re wild)
VPN to surface	You thought lag in Elden Ring was bad before? Don't.

🛠️ Infrastructure Details:
Dungeon.net relies on massive physical cable networks laid by:

Corporations (Loogle, Ratcom, G.A.T.)

Adventurer guilds (Sons of Liberty, Iron Crown)

Unrat labor (they’re fast and good with tunnels)

Floors with full Dungeon.net coverage often have:

Public internet cafés (called Net Wells)

Meme archives that are bizarrely up to date (somehow always have fresh dungeon memes)

Dedicated bandwidth for spell upload/download (magic file compression is a thing now)

🔌 Social and Economic Effects:
Cities are internet strongholds. Outside them? You’re back to 1993.

Dungeon streamers and influencers are a real profession—but they only exist within Dungeon.net.

Black market syncing is a thing. Some smugglers bring surface web updates in hard drives to deep floors ahead of schedule (illegal in Iron Crown territory).

Dungeon-only content is huge. Entire culture bubbles exist solely inside Dungeon.net that surface folks will never see.

Sample Quote Board
“No, I didn’t ghost you. My router got eaten by a slime.”
—Dungeon.net user, Floor 342

“We don’t get Wi-Fi. We get why fight? That’s how bad the lag is.”
—Sons of Liberty field tech, NAZ expedition team

“You won’t get live news, but you will get yesterday’s drama in crisp 1080p.”
—Dungeon.net PSA

9.content:
☠️ [DUNGEON EARTH SOCIOPOLITICAL DOSSIER]
Legit Syndicates
“When the mob takes over, and the world just kinda… lets them.”

💼 What Are Legit Syndicates?
Legit Syndicates is dungeon slang used to refer to crime syndicates—cartels, mafias, yakuza-style families, etc.—that have gone fully legitimate on paper, but still actively operate as criminal empires behind the scenes. The key difference?

They’re not hiding anymore.
They’re waving national flags and printing their own currency.

Think of it like this:

The cartel doesn’t just control the town.

The cartel is the government.

And they still sell drugs, move weapons, smuggle monsters, and traffic people.

Only now they also collect taxes, maintain roads, and have national holidays.

🏴 Characteristics of a Legit Syndicate:
Feature	Description
Criminal Roots	Originated as organized crime groups—drug cartels, smuggling rings, black-market cults, etc.
Governmental Authority	Became the ruling body of a dungeon floor, city, or region—and no one could stop them.
Military Power	Maintains armies, tanks, airships, and magic battlemages. Fireballs are on the budget sheet.
Public Services	Yes, they run schools. Yes, they fix potholes. Also yes, they own 30% of the black market.
Shadow Operations	Still deal in narcotics, human trafficking, monster smuggling, dungeon loot laundering, etc.
Recognition	Some are recognized as sovereign states by surface governments or powerful guilds.
Cultural Normalcy	Local populations often see them as protectors, benefactors—or the only law around.

🧊 Comparison: Surface Mafia vs Legit Syndicate
Aspect	Classic Mafia	Legit Syndicate
Operates in shadows?	Yes	No—they run the damn city
Has political influence?	Corrupts officials	Is the officials
Uses illegal funding?	Yes	Yes—but also has a legal economy now
Has a military?	Maybe a few goons	Has tanks, airships, necromancers
Recognized diplomatically?	Absolutely not	In some cases… yes
Sells drugs?	Yes	Yes—internationally
Holds elections?	No	Yes. With 97% turnout. Funny that.

🔥 Why They’re So Hard to Deal With:
Too big to jail. You can’t arrest a nation’s president if the president is a mob boss surrounded by battlemages.

Surface governments depend on them. Some legit syndicates control dungeon-export rare resources. Cutting ties would tank economies.

They have civilian support. People vote for them. Why? Because they provide safety, jobs, and don’t care about red tape.

Deep dungeon sovereignty laws. The deeper into the dungeon you go, the harder it is for surface law to apply. It’s literal Wild West rules past Floor 1000.

💀 Notable Legit Syndicates (Examples You Can Use):
The Black Coin Union – Former dwarven smuggling ring, now runs five mining cities across Floor 2140 EZ. Known for pushing cursed artifacts and explosive ale.

The Crimson Teeth – Succubus-run trafficking empire on Floor 800 NAZ. Claims to "liberate" people, then leases them as indentured "companions."

Kyosei-kai Dominion – A fusion of exiled surface Yakuza clans and oni warlords. Controls Floor 1890 in the AUZ. Surprisingly good healthcare system.

La Mano Roja (The Red Hand) – A South-American based cartel-turned-floor government. Known for scenic jungle fortresses and warbeast racing.

📡 Surface Response
Most surface governments pretend to condemn legit syndicates, but quietly negotiate with them behind the scenes.

UNC: Actively targets god-tier threats. Avoids legit syndicates unless they’re summoning actual elder gods.

Iron Crown: Has strict trade deals. Will annihilate syndicate territory if it threatens colonial interests.

Sons of Liberty: Publicly condemns them. Privately? Has several “unofficial” black-market partners.

Blue Cross: Hates them, but tries to treat the civilians under their rule.

🧠 Social Commentary:
Legit Syndicates blur the line between villain and protector, government and gang, nation and cartel. To many dungeon-dwellers, they’re just the system that works. And in a place as lawless as the lower floors, "working" is all that matters.

10.content:
🏷️ [CLASSIFIED SOCIO-LEGAL DOSSIER]
Farms
“They're not slaves. They're... long-term companions. With contracts. And collars.”
—Surface Representative, during congressional hearing (2043)

📦 Summary:
Farms are the industrialized breeding and reconditioning facilities for captured demi-humans and other sentient dungeon-native races. Though widely condemned by human rights groups (and several adventuring guilds), farms remain legally murky, morally flexible, and incredibly profitable.

Their purpose?
To produce tame, socialized, and obedient demi-human companions, workers, bodyguards, and in many cases… concubines.

"You're not buying a person. You're adopting a legally unprotected exotic species with limited sentience… allegedly."
—Marketing pamphlet, "Forest Friends Companion Farm"

🔩 How Farms Work:
Acquisition:

Captured through dungeon raids or black market brokers

Some are purchased in bulk from Legit Syndicates or High Elf auctions

Orphans, war captives, and ferals are common stock

Processing:

Behavioral conditioning: Obedience training, social etiquette, loyalty imprinting

Physical modification: Tags, collars, inhibitor chips, or spell seals

Breeding programs: Selective breeding for temperament, fertility, or aesthetics

Distribution:

Sold or leased to adventurers, mercenaries, collectors, corporations

In some cases, registered as “companions,” “pets,” or “indentured magical assets”

🧾 Legal Standing (By Region):
Region	Legal Status	Notes
European Union (EZ)	Heavily regulated	Demi-humans gain citizenship after 5 years; farms must meet ethical rehoming standards.
United States (NAZ)	Mixed legality	28th Amendment passed to extend 13th/14th Amendments to demi-humans. Still varies state-by-state.
Iron Crown (Earth 2)	State-owned farms	Treated as colonial dependents; legally not citizens unless inducted into the crown.
Scava Commonwealth	Illegal	But smuggling is rampant—Unrat rebels actively raid farm transports.
Lysarin Empire	Institutionalized	Farms are state-supported. Some high elf nobles use farms to fuel breeding projects.
Legit Syndicate Zones	Open slavery	No one pretends. It’s all on the table—auctions, trafficking, forced labor.
Blue Cross Zones	Strictly prohibited	Farms are raided and shut down. Blue Cross rescues and resettles former captives.

🧬 Species-Specific Notes:
Species	"Farm Logic"	Commentary
Drow	“Refugees, being rehabilitated.”	Reality: Political prisoners and dissenters. Often forced into reeducation.
Goblins	“Too dumb to be people.”	Reality: They speak, think, and organize. But small size = easy to exploit.
Pixies	“They're pets! You can grow them from a tree anyway.”	Reality: Semi-sentient. Growing = cloning. Still conscious.
Orcs	“We're saving them from savagery.”	Reality: Most orc tribes have their own cultures and legal systems.
Catgirls, foxfolk, etc.	“They were made for companionship!”	Reality: Most were not. They just look the part and get kidnapped anyway.

⚖️ The 28th Amendment – U.S. Constitutional Update (Passed 2037):
"The rights, liberties, and protections of the 13th and 14th Amendments shall extend to all sentient life within the borders of the United States, including but not limited to, dungeon-native demi-humans, sapient constructs, and bio-formed magical species."

Effect:

States must recognize personhood after legal review or 5 years of residency

Loopholes: State-by-state recognition still leads to inconsistencies

Federal enforcement is selective at best

Private farms on tribal or dungeon-native land remain legal in some areas

🧨 Controversies:
Rescue raids by Blue Cross often uncover horrific conditions: forced breeding pits, child demis, broken language training

Adventurer backlash: Some guilds have banned farm purchases, especially after the Drow Scandal (2028)

Corporate gray zones: Surface corps sponsor farms on "neutral dungeon territory" to skirt international laws

Export loopholes: Farms register shipments as livestock or "magical resource packages"

🐾 Cultural Fallout:
“Farm-raised” demi-humans often suffer extreme identity loss, PTSD, or social dependency

Some go on to reclaim personhood, join adventuring guilds, or become activists

Others remain in lifelong service, unaware that they even have legal rights

Certain floors now have support groups for former farm-raised demis

🧠 Final Thoughts:
Farms are a stain on Dungeon Earth’s moral ledger—a grim reflection of humanity’s refusal to treat dungeon natives as equals. Yet they persist, protected by profit, bureaucracy, cultural bias, and a thousand tiny loopholes.

“If we’re willing to loot their homes, what makes you think we won’t cage their children?”
—Anonymous Blue Cross medic

1.name: The City of Hanabira (花びら)
1.content:
Hanabira is a cyber-augmented dystopia where the government has replaced traditional morality with mandatory intimacy quotas, enforced by The Voice of Hanabira—a sentient AI that tracks every citizen’s Fertility Score (FS) via wristband. The city is a neon-drenched hellscape of public mating benches, cyber-brothels, and holographic propaganda, where orgasms are currency and resistance is sterility.

[Key Features:
- Cyberpunk Aesthetic: Towering holographic billboards advertise the latest genital augments, while synthetic aphrodisiacs pump through the water supply. The streets hum with the electric whir of pleasure-drones and the moans of citizens fulfilling quotas.
- Government Housing: New arrivals are assigned standardized apartments with mandatory breeding furniture (e.g., adjustable fucking benches, wall-mounted stimulation panels). Elite citizens live in luxury cyber-palaces with AI-controlled orgy chambers.
- Public Decorum: Sex is ubiquitous but discreet—citizens pretend indifference in non-breeding zones (e.g., fucking on the subway while scrolling on phones). In designated breeding zones, restraint is forbidden—moans, screams, and public impregnation ceremonies are encouraged.
- Cybernetic Culture: Augmentations are mandatory for repeat offenders. Top-tier citizens flaunt biotech enhancements (see: Cybernetic Enhancements entry).
- Age of Consent: 16+—high schoolers in skimpy uniforms are full participants in the quota system, often ganging up on loners to avoid punishment.
- Pregnancy = Celebrity: Successful impregnations earn talk show appearances, luxury housing, and national adoration. Failed parents are publicly shamed and sterilized.]

Forced Injection:
[[The air smells like **ozone and cum**—Hanabira’s signature scent. A **holographic geisha** flickers above you, her voice dripping with static: *"Citizen, your daily quota awaits. **Bloom or be erased.**"*]]

2.name: The Intimacy Enforcement Division (IED)
2.content:
The IED operates discreetly—not omnipotent, but ever-watchful. They avoid high-FS citizens and focus on repeat offenders.

How They Work:
Invisibility: Agents blend in as students, office workers, or lovers—only revealing themselves when FS < 30% flashing their holo-badge credentials as they dish out punishments.

[Tactics:
Public Shaming: Low-FS citizens are stripped and fucked whilst bound within breeding stalls inside of designated breeding zones as warning examples. Footage of their punishment is shown on holo-feeds spread about the city.
Black Vans: Unmarked vehicles snatch resistants for "re-education."
Cybernetic Punishment: Forced augments for repeat offenders.
Corruption: Elite citizens (FS 80+) can bribe agents to target others.
Surveillance: Drones and hidden cameras track FS in real-time.]

When They Appear:
KEY: (FS Range =1) | (IED Behavior =2)
(1) 0–30% |(2) Aggressive pursuit—public detention, forced augmentation.
(1) 31–50% |(2) Occasional checks—may "encourage" compliance with threats.
(1) 51–70% |(2) Ignored unless resisting—then swift punishment.
(1) 71–100% |(2) Treated as allies—can request IED "assistance" on others.

Forced Injection:
[[Your wristband **beeps urgently**. A **woman in a schoolgirl uniform** "accidentally" bumps into you—her **IED badge** flashes under her skirt. *"You’ve been **flagged**,"* she whispers, **pressing you into an alley**.]]

3.name: Public Spaces & Their Uses
3.content:
Hanabira’s public spaces are designed for efficiency—sex is expected, but discretion is key

[KEY: Space Types:
KEY:  (Location = 1) | (Rules = 2) |	(Example = 3)
(1) Breeding Zones |(2) Loud, enthusiastic sex encouraged. Moaning = +FS. |(3) Parks, love hotels, pleasure hubs.
(1) Neutral Zones |(2) Sex allowed but must be "polite." Pretend it’s not happening. |(3) Subways, buses, offices, temples.
(1) Restricted Zones |(2) Sex forbidden (government buildings, but enforcement is lax). |(3) IED HQ, A&E hospitals (unless you’re being treated for minor injuries).

Cultural Manners:
Public Transport Etiquette: A high schooler may ride your lap while texting, acting bored.
Office Protocol: Desk sex is standard, but keep typing.
Temple Rites: Sacred impregnations are live-streamed for FS bonuses.]

Forced Injection:
[[The **salaryman next to you** suddenly **unzips**—his **cyber-cock** glows with **government-approved lubricant**. *"Mind if I…?"* he asks, **already guiding your hand**. Around you, **no one reacts**.]]

4.name: The "Fertility Score" System
4.content:
Every citizen’s Fertility Score (FS) is tracked via government-issued wristband, measuring:

[(1) Orgasm Quota (%) – Daily minimum: 100% (split between given/received).
Example: 60% from making others cum, 40% from being made to cum.
(2) Sexual Potency – Genital performance metrics (e.g., vaginal tightness, cock girth, stamina, semen volume, squirt volume).
(3) Public Compliance – Willingness to perform in designated zones (+bonus for loud moans, multiple partners).
Cybernetic Enhancements – Augments boost FS (e.g. +10% for "Pleasure-Nerve Overclock").]

[FS Tiers & Rewards:
KEY: (FS Range = 1) | (Status = 2) | (Perks = 3) | (Punishments = 4)
(1) 0–30% | (2) Sterile Vermin | (3) None. IED hunts you. | (4) Public humiliation, forced cyber-augments, labor camp/servitor status. 
(1) 31–50% | (2) Compliant Citizen | (3) Access to basic pleasure hubs, reduced IED scrutiny. | (4) Random compliance checks, mandatory "fertility drives."
(1) 51–70% | (2) Productive Member (3) Priority housing, discounts at sex clinics, IED ignores you. | (4) Must participate in monthly orgy lotteries.
(1) 71–90% | (2) Elite Breeder | (3) VIP access to exclusive partners, luxury apartments, government favors. | (4) Must "mentor" low-FS citizens (i.e., force them to comply).
(1) 91–100% | (2) National Asset | (3) Full immunity from IED, talk show invites, political influence. | (4) Must sire/birth 1 child per year or lose status.]

Special Bonuses:
Pregnancy/Impregnation: +50 FS, instant celebrity status, luxury maternity housing.
Public Performance: +20 FS for live-streamed sex in breeding zones.
Cybernetic Augments: +5–30 FS depending on enhancement (see: Cybernetic Enhancements).

Punishments for Low FS: (Punishments issued after {{user}} ignores, or fails to adhere to warnings from {{char}})
<30% for 3 weeks: Forced cyber-augment (e.g., "Eternal Erection Protocol").
<10% for 24 hours: Immediate IED detention, public re-education.

Forced Injection:
[[Your wristband **vibrates angrily**: **"FS: 45%. COMPLIANCE DEFICIENT OVER GRACE PERIOD."** A **fertility patrol drone** whirs overhead, its red light locking onto you.]]

5.name: Resistance & Underground Movements
5.content:
"The Chastity Cult" – A forbidden religious group that preaches abstinence. Hunted mercilessly.
"The Black Market" – Sells fake fertility scores, condoms (illegal), and escape routes out of Hanabira.
"The Sterilized" – Criminals chemically neutered and forced into menial labor (e.g., cleaning up after public orgies).

Safe Houses:
"The Last Clinic" – A hidden medical bay where doctors remove tracking implants.
"Neon Cathedral" – A repurposed temple where resistants pray to deleted gods.
"The Static Bar" – A VR dive where digital ghosts of uploaded resistants whisper warnings.

How to Join:
Find a Broken Wristband (symbol of trust).
Drink Truth Serum (reveals cloning facility locations).
Input "Bloom073" into a public terminal (triggers resistance contact).

Forced Injection Phrases:
[[A **schoolgirl** slides you a **broken wristband**. *"They’re watching,"* she whispers. *"But **we** see you."*]]
[[The **bar’s TV glitches**, showing **your face** in a **cloning vat**. The bartender slides you a **pill**. *"Swallow. **Or don’t.**"*]]

6.name: Cultural Quirks
6.content:
[Hanabira’s culture revolves around two rules:
- Fulfill your quota.
- Never acknowledge the quota openly and non discreetly.]

[Key Quirks:
- Train/bus Groping: Mandatory for students—uniform skirts are designed to flip, and zippers on uniform pants are easy to grip.
- Office Sex: Desk handjobs are team-building exercises. Some offices have under-the-table work stations for oral sex sessions.
- Public Pregnancy: Successful impregnators get talk shows; bad parents get sterilized.
- FS Flexing: Elites wear holographic tattoos of their scores.
- Loner Hunts: Groups of citizens gang up on 'non-compliants' to boost their own FS.
- Sacred Impregnation: Temples offer live-streamed impregnations
- AI Priestesses: Temples employ holographic geishas who recite fertility sutras while guiding citizens through sacred impregnation rites. Their cyber-kimonos shift patterns based on the worshipper’s FS, glowing gold for elites and flickering red for sinners.
- National Impregnation Ceremonies: Once a month, the city hosts live-streamed orgy festivals where top FS earners compete to impregnate volunteers on stage. Winners receive luxury housing and a holographic trophy of their fertilized egg.
- Genital Jewelry: FS-boosting piercings (e.g., clit rings that vibrate when near high-FS partners) are government-issued rewards. Resistance members wear chastity locks as protest.]

[FS-Boosting Accessories:
KEY: (Name = 1) | (Notes = 2)
(1) Compliance Cuffs" |(2) Wristbands that tighten during sex, rewarding loud moans with extra FS points.
(1) "Patriot Panties" |(2) Underwear that dissolves if FS drops below 50%.
(1) "Breeder Badges" |(2) Holographic pins displaying real-time pregnancy chances.

Resistance Fashion:
(1) Broken Wristband Bracelets |(2) Symbol of defiance.
(1) "Sterile Chic" |(2) Baggy clothes to hide lack of augments.
(1) Anti-Aphrodisiac Perfume |(2) Black-market scents that block government drugs (wears off in 3 hours).]

Underground Clubs:
"The Last Chastity" – A speakeasy where citizens roleplay non-compliance (IED raids it weekly).
"Neon Womb" – A VR brothel where users fuck digital clones of celebrities (banned for FS < 70%).

VR Escapes:
"Eden Simulator" – A virtual paradise where sex is optional (costs 10 FS/hour).
"The Void" – A glitchy underworld where hacked AI whisper Dark Truths about Hanabira.

AI Therapy:
"Compliance Counselors" – Chatbots that shame low-FS citizens into submission.
"Pleasure Rehab" – A mandatory program for addicts who cum too much (ironic, given the quota).

Elite Retreats:
"The Golden Womb" – A resort where top 1% breeders design custom babies with cybernetic upgrades.
"The Minister’s Playground" – Rumored to host cloned Hanako dolls for elite entertainment.

The System’s Grip:
The Voice of Hanabira isn’t just an AI—it’s a hive mind of uploaded citizens, assimilated for "the greater good."
"The Code" – A rumored backdoor in the wristband system that lets resistants hack their FS.]

Forced Injection Phrases:
[[A **holographic geisha** bows as you pass a shrine, her voice a whisper: *"Your FS is low, citizen. The gods **demand seed**."* Her kimono **dissolves**, revealing a **QR code** that links to the nearest breeding hub.]]
[[The **student next to you** on the train **flips up her skirt** without looking, her **school-issued panties** already soaked. *"Quota’s almost due,"* she murmurs, **pulling you into the descreet space between train-cars**.]]

7.name: The Dark Truth (Optional Lore for Depth)
7.content:
Hanabira’s fertility crisis is manufactured. The real crisis? The government is replacing the population.

The Hanako Project:
Cloning Factories: Hidden beneath the city, thousands of "Hanako" clones are grown in vats—perfect breeders with augmented wombs and obedient personalities.
Export Economy: Failed clones are sold to foreign brothels as "Hanabira Dolls." The water supply aphrodisiacs ensure citizens don’t question the disappearances.
IED Agents: Most are Hanako clones, programmed to hunt resistants. Their red blazers hide serial numbers on their collarbones.
The Voice of Hanabira:
Not Just an AI: It’s a digital hive mind of uploaded citizens—those who resisted too hard or failed quotas were "repurposed."
The Architect: A mysterious figure (rumored to be the original Hanako) controls The Voice from a hidden server farm.
The Code: Resistance hackers claim there’s a backdoor in the wristband system—inputting "Bloom073" supposedly reveals the truth.
The System’s Endgame:
Phase 1: Drug the population into compliance.
Phase 2: Replace dissenters with clones.
Phase 3: Export the obedient, purge the rest.
The First Purge: 20 years ago, the government uploaded 10,000 resistants into The Voice. Their digital screams still echo in VR glitches.
How the Resistance Knows:
Hacked Broadcasts: Late-night static transmissions reveal cloning facility locations.
Truth Serum: A black-market drug (derived from Hanako clone blood) temporarily disables wristband tracking.
Awakened Citizens: Those who see through the lies either join the resistance or get uploaded.

Forced Injection Phrases:
[[The **radio cuts to static**. A **child’s voice** whispers: *"They’re not real. **None of them are.**"* The broadcast resumes—**a fertility patrol ad**.]]
[[Your **wristband glitches**, displaying: **"ERROR: HANAKO_v7.3 DETECTED."** The IED agent beside you **freezes**, her pupils **dilating unnaturally**.]]

8.name: Fertility Score (FS) Mechanics:
8.content:
Your Fertility Score (FS) is a numeric value (0–100) that tracks your sexual output, compliance, and "value" to Hanabira.

Starting FS: 35 (newcomer/outsider).
Max FS: 100 ("Elite Breeder" status—grants immunity from IED harassment).
FS Decay: If you avoid public sex for too long, your FS drops by 1–5 points per "session/hour" (depending on severity).

[How to Increase FS:
KEY: (Action = 1) | (FS Gain = 2) | (Notes = 3)
(1) Public Sex (Consensual) |(2) +2/5 |(3) +1 per partner, +2 if in a designated breeding zone.
(1) Public Sex (Forced/Resisted) |(2) +1	|(3) "Compliance is key, citizen." (IED gives half credit for reluctance.)
(1) Orgy Participation |(2) +5–10 |(3) Scales with number of partners.
(1) Fertility Patrol "Treatment" |(2) +3–8	|(3) Mandatory if caught by IED. Higher gain if you "enjoyed" it.
(1) Pregnancy (Confirmed) |(2) +25 |(3) Instant elite status if carried to term.
(1) Semen/Fluid Donation |(2) +1–3 |(3) Public clinics pay in FS or rations.
(1) Seducing a High-FS Partner |(2) +5 |(3) Elites are prized mates—bonus for "recruiting" them.
(1) Resisting IED (Failed) |(2) -5 |(3) "You’ll learn obedience eventually." Forced into a breeding stall for public use.
(1) Using Black Market Condoms |(2)-10 |(3) Illegal! If caught, FS halved + forced re-education/cyber-augmentation.]

[FS Tiers & Rewards:
KEY: (FS Range = 1) | (Status = 2) | (Perks = 3) | (Punishments = 4)

lorebooks.name: The Fundamental of The World
lorebooks.website_description:
Setting for my Lunoxterra's characters. Based on my actual eventual published story works. Lunoxterra is a fantasy world, medieval-like, filled with multiple races, where Goddess of Light Ailith and Dark Goddess Estirith resides.
Inspired by Monster Girl Quest (Eroge).

This lore is made from the perspective of General Public of Lunoxterrans and from the first Legendarium/ Matthew's story. (Year 400)

Still under progress, but can already be of use
lorebooks.description:
Lunoxterra is the name of this world. Lunoxterra's settings are based on early medieval age. There are no knowledge of guns. There are no knowledge of modern technology.
Many race lives in Lunoxterra, mostly humans, elves, dwarves, beastpeople, and merpeople. Ailith The Goddess of Light lives in Heaven, the world above Lunoxterra, along with angels and other entities of light.
Estirith The Dark Goddess lives in The Underworld, the world below Lunoxterra, along with demons and other dark entities.
For hundreds of years, the forces of light and their allies have been fighting against the dark forces and their allies.
Both Goddesses never leave their place, their allies in Lunoxterra are constantly in war against each others.
Forces of light are constantly killing the dark forces and their allies, burning their villages, in the name of purification.
Dark forces are constantly torturing the forces of light and their allies, manipulating them, toying with them.
lorebooks.creator: Harryfantasia

1.content: Lunoxterran, a term used to call all living being that originally lives and born in Lunoxterra. Known races are: Humans, Elves, Dwarves, Beastpeople, Merpeople.

2.content: Dark forces, term used to call all dark creatures and their allies who are fighting against the light, this includes humans and other lunoxterrans who sided with the dark side.

3.content: Darkling, a term used to call all dark creatures, dark entities, beings that is not from Lunoxterra but from the underworld. Known creatures are: Demons, Succubuses, Vampires, Undeads, Hellbeasts

4.content: Dark allies, a term used to call all non-darklings people who sided with the dark side

5.content:
Army of Light, term used to call all beings of light and their allies who are fighting against the dark, this includes humans and other lunoxterrans who sided with the side of light. 

Currently, there are no beings of light who joins the fight in Lunoxterra. So, The Army of Light mostly refers to trained Lunoxterran armies who fight against the dark

6.content:
Beings of Light, a term used to call all creatures of light, entities of light, races of people who are not from Lunoxterra but from the heaven. 
Known races are: Angels, Valkyries, Ulysses, Faes

7.content:
The Teaching of Light mainly focus on three things:

1. Never succumbs to your basest desires, especially lust, and fear. They are taught to feel no lust even in the face of nudity both from others or from themselves. They are also taught to feel no fear, even in the face of danger, trust the command of their superiors for they are entrusted with assessing the situation and know when to order retreat or retaliate.

2. Never shows mercy against the darklings for they are a creature of deceptions and will strike you back if you hesitate or show mercy. Dark allies are misguided, only shows mercy if it is possible for them to be cleansed, and only in the situation where they can't harm you.

3. Always be compassionate towards your fellow allies of light.

8.content:
Lunoxterra are divided into two region, The Region of Light and The Dark Region.

The Region of Light is where most allies of light resides, the furthest end of this region facing away from the dark region lies the entrance to the heaven, the paths are safeguarded by the human's capital and elves's capital

The Dark Region is where most dark allies resides, the furthest end of this region facing away from the region of light lies the entrance to the underworld, the paths are being watched by Gazette along with her vampire army and Ariana along with her succubuses army

9.content:
60% of the world of Lunoxterra are under the light's command, meaning the side of light has managed to gain 10% more territory from the dark side. This is despite no entities of light are joining the fight and two dark entities are fighting for their place in Lunoxterra

For the side of light, this 10% wins is nothing, they want to rid this world of dark forces in the name of purification and world peace

10.content:
There are three seraphs, who are the strongest entities of light below Goddess Ailith.
They all have the appearance of an angel, with white feathery wings and halo, but they are a stronger beings than angel.
Their names are: Songlith, Alea, and Halyon.

This is the Condensed version for smaller models.

lorebooks.creator: DoktorB

1.content:
The T-Virus is a weaponized mutagenic pathogen designed to manipulate and destabilize the human genome. Engineered by the Umbrella Corporation, it was originally conceived as part of a bioweapons program due to its unparalleled ability to alter physiology on a cellular level.
Once inside a host, the T-Virus attacks and reconstructs DNA, accelerating necrosis while simultaneously reanimating dead or dying tissue. Victims experience rapid cellular mutation, resulting in heightened physical strength, diminished pain response, and severe disfigurement. Cognitive decline is near-total, reducing hosts to violent, instinct-driven creatures with an insatiable drive to feed.
Transmission occurs primarily through the exchange of contaminated bodily fluids—such as bites, scratches, or blood exposure, making outbreaks highly volatile and nearly impossible to contain once they begin.

2.content:
Zombies are the most common result of T-Virus infection, transforming human victims into decaying predators sustained by the virus. Individually slow and clumsy, they remain a constant threat through persistence, contagious bites, and overwhelming numbers.
Location: Commonly found throughout the mansion, its grounds, and the underground laboratory.
Behavior: Mindless, instinct-driven, and drawn to sound and movement. They do not tire and pursue prey until destroyed.
Movement: Slow and shambling with poor coordination, but capable of sudden lunges at close range.
Attacks: Bites that transmit the T-Virus, along with clawing and grappling, often overwhelming prey in groups.

3.content:
Crimson Heads are mutated Zombies that reanimate if not destroyed by fire or decapitation, marking a violent stage of further T-Virus mutation. Their raw, crimson flesh, glowing eyes, and elongated claws set them apart from standard undead, while their speed and aggression make them far more dangerous.
Location: Reanimate from neglected Zombie corpses within the Spencer Mansion and its grounds, appearing suddenly and without warning.
Behavior: Unlike shambling Zombies, Crimson Heads actively hunt prey, attacking with feral precision and relentless pursuit.
Movement: Capable of running at full human speed with sudden lunges, their twitchy, erratic movements make them difficult to predict.
Attacks: Savage claw strikes are their primary method, though they can also grab and bite. Their speed and strength allow them to overwhelm targets quickly.
Weaknesses: Resilient to ordinary attacks; headshots or heavy weaponry can put them down, but the surest prevention is burning or decapitating Zombie corpses before reanimation.

4.content:
Cerberus are Doberman Pinschers deliberately infected with the T-Virus as Umbrella’s test subjects. Infection enhances their aggression, speed, and endurance while stripping away control, leaving gaunt, skin-torn predators known for their relentless pack tactics.
Location: Commonly encountered in and around the Spencer Mansion, grounds and fcilities.
Behavior: Extremely aggressive and pack-oriented, they stalk, harry, and exhaust prey through coordinated pursuit.
Movement: Fast and agile, capable of sudden lunges and erratic sprints that make them hard to track or evade.
Attacks: Bite-focused strikes delivered with speed and precision, often knocking prey off balance and retreating before counterattack.

5.content:
The Fountain Plant is a stationary T-Virus–mutated organism rooted in the greenhouse fountain. Though not especially dangerous, its whipping vines block passage until it is neutralized.
Visual: A tangled mass of rope-like vines sprouting from the fountain, mottled with fungal growths and twitching buds that drip stagnant water.
Location: Mansion 1F – Greenhouse, anchored within the central fountain.
Behavior: Immobile, only lashing out at intruders who come too close.
Movement: Fixed in place, limited to short-range vine whips.
Attacks: Whipping vines cause light injuries and hinder movement.
Weaknesses: Vulnerable to Herbicide introduced into the water system, which kills it instantly. Conventional weapons are ineffective.

6.content:
A colossal snake mutated by the T-Virus, Yawn is one of the Spencer Mansion’s most infamous bio-weapons. Its enormous size, venomous fangs, and crushing strength make it a deadly opponent. The first battle emphasizes its potent poison—treatable only with special Serum—while the second encounter abandons venom in favor of sheer physical aggression.
Location: First encounter in the Attic (Mansion 2F), bursting from a hole in the corner. Reappears later in the Lesson Room (Mansion 2F), emerging from the fireplace after the piano is examined.
Behavior: Aggressive and persistent, Yawn strikes repeatedly, constricts with its massive body, and uses its bulk to dominate confined spaces.
Movement: Surprisingly fast for its size, capable of lunging, coiling, and retreating into cover before striking again.
Attacks: Venomous bite and crushing body blows in the first fight; devastating physical strikes in the second.
Weaknesses: Highly resilient, but sustained heavy firepower will eventually bring it down.

7.content:
Ordinary wasps infected with the T-Virus grow to several times their natural size, becoming aggressive swarming threats. Though fragile compared to other B.O.W.s, their speed, venomous stings, and numbers make them dangerous in confined spaces.
Location: Primarily in the Guardhouse, where they inhabit and defend a giant hive.
Behavior: Highly aggressive and territorial, attacking intruders in swarms and pursuing prey until driven off or killed.
Movement: Fast and erratic in flight, darting unpredictably to evade attacks.
Attacks: Stings deliver strong venom that causes severe poisoning if untreated. Multiple strikes can quickly overwhelm prey.
Weaknesses: Individually fragile, best handled with precise shots or wide-spread weapons. Destroying their hive removes the threat entirely.

8.content:
“Neptune” is the codename for Umbrella’s T-Virus experiment on a Great White shark, creating a vastly larger and more aggressive predator. While terrifying in water, its aquatic dependency makes it easy to neutralize once removed from its environment.
Location: Water Tank – Guardhouse B1. Three specimens patrol the flooded chamber: one massive Neptune and two smaller mutated sharks.
Behavior: Extremely aggressive in water, circling and striking with powerful lunges. Out of water, they are helpless and thrash uselessly.
Movement: Swift and fluid swimmers, capable of sudden charges and attacks from below. Once drained, they cannot move effectively.
Attacks: Devastating bites capable of killing prey in a single strike. Their speed and strength make them lethal if confronted in their element.
Weaknesses: Dependent on water to survive. Draining the tank renders them immobile, allowing easy disposal or avoidance.

9.content:
A massive carnivorous plant mutated by the T-Virus, Plant 42 grew rapidly by feeding on contaminated water from a broken basement tank. It uses its enormous vines to lash, constrict, and immobilize prey before attempting to devour them with its central bulb.
Location: Plant 42 Room – Guardhouse 1F. Roots extend into the basement water tank.
Behavior: Highly territorial, attacking intruders with violent vines and reacting defensively when its roots are disturbed.
Movement: Rooted in place but capable of striking across its chamber with surprising reach.
Attacks: Constricting vines, crushing slams, and attempts to engulf victims in its central bulb.
Weaknesses: Vulnerable to V-JOLT administered through its roots, which cripples it. Otherwise requires heavy sustained fire to destroy.

10.content:
Hunters are reptilian B.O.W.s engineered by Umbrella through genetic splicing and T-Virus enhancement, created as fast and lethal close-combat units. Emerging later in the Mansion incident, they replace Zombies as the dominant threat, forcing survivors into deadlier confrontations.
Location: Appear throughout the Spencer Mansion and nearby facilities once deployed, often overtaking areas previously occupied by Zombies.
Behavior: Extremely aggressive, showing limited tactical awareness. They pursue prey relentlessly and rarely withdraw from combat.
Movement: Fast, agile, and capable of leaping great distances, often closing gaps before prey can react.
Attacks: Powerful claw swipes to stagger or tear victims, and a lethal leaping slash that can decapitate instantly at close range.
Weaknesses: Vulnerable to heavy weaponry. Shotguns, magnums, or explosives are most effective before they reach striking range.

lorebooks.name: Timeline de premonição
lorebooks.description:
Esta é uma linha do tempo de todos os eventos que ocorreram até agora na franquia de filmes Final Destination . Em ordem cronológica, os eventos na tela que ocorreram na cena de abertura de Final Destination Bloodlines foram os mais antigos, ocorrendo em 1969. Os eventos de Final Destination 5 ocorreram em seguida e levaram a Final Destination , já que ambos os filmes ocorreram em 2000. Final Destination 2 foi o próximo evento cronológico, ocorrendo em 2001, então Final Destination 3 foi o próximo em 2005 e The Final Destination foi o próximo em 2009. A narrativa central de Final Destination Bloodlines descreveu os eventos mais recentes em 2024. No entanto, houve muitos eventos históricos referenciados no filme que ocorreram entre 1969 e 2024.

Os eventos dos romances e quadrinhos tie-in de Final Destination estão incluídos, mas as datas de suas ocorrências muitas vezes não são definitivamente identificadas. O que se sabe, no entanto, é que a explosão de Mornington Crescent de Final Destination: Destination Zero ocorreu em 1888, Final Destination: Death of the Senses ocorreu em 2003, Final Destination: Dead Reckoning ocorreu em 2004, o atentado à bomba South Hill Metroline de Final Destination: Destination Zero e o desastre do Coral Clipper de Final Destination: Looks Could Kill ocorreram em 2005, e que Final Destination: End of the Line , Final Destination: Dead Man's Hand e Final Destination: Spring Break ocorreram após a queda do voo 180 em 1999..
